expanded_description: The substitution method becomes even more powerful when applied to complex systems involving fractions, decimals, parentheses, or equations that require significant manipulation. This section builds on the basic substitution skills and introduces strategies for handling more challenging systems, including those where careful planning is needed to choose which variable to isolate.

core_concept.principle: Advanced substitution follows the same principles as basic substitution, but requires additional algebraic skills: clearing fractions, distributing carefully, and making strategic choices about which variable to isolate. The goal remains to reduce a system of two equations to a single equation in one variable.
core_concept.explanation: Think of advanced substitution as solving a puzzle with more complicated pieces. The strategy is the same—find a piece that can be expressed in terms of another—but the pieces themselves may have fractions, decimals, or parentheses that need careful handling. With practice, you'll learn to spot the easiest path through the complexity.

image.caption: Figure 7.4.1: Advanced substitution handles more complex equations.

sections.section_title: 7.4.1 Review: Choosing Which Variable to Isolate
sections.introduction: When neither variable is already isolated, we must choose which one to solve for. This choice can make the problem easier or harder.

key_concept.definition:
When deciding which variable to isolate, look for:
• A variable with coefficient 1 or -1
• A variable that appears in both equations with simple coefficients
• An equation that can be solved without introducing fractions
The right choice can significantly simplify your work.
key_concept.context: Taking a moment to consider your options before starting can save time and reduce errors.

image.caption: Figure 7.4.3: Choosing the best variable to isolate.

worked_examples.title: Strategic Variable Selection

image.caption: Figure 7.4.4: For each system, decide which variable to isolate and why.

worked_examples.problem:
For each system, decide which variable you would isolate and explain why:
a) $\begin{cases} 3x + 2y = 12 \\ 4x - y = 5 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 2x + 5y = 10 \\ 3x - 2y = 7 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} x + 3y = 8 \\ 2x - y = 4 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: In second equation, $y$ has coefficient -1, making it easy to isolate
All coefficients are 2,5,3,-2 - no coefficient of 1. Either variable requires fractions
step_by_step.calculation: Could isolate either; perhaps $x$ from first: $x = \frac{10 - 5y}{2}$

step_by_step.explanation: First equation has $x$ with coefficient 1, very easy to isolate

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) Isolate y from second equation (coefficient -1)
b) Either, both will involve fractions
c) Isolate x from first equation (coefficient 1)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Choose the variable with coefficient 1 or -1 when possible to avoid fractions.

sections.introduction: When equations contain fractions, it's often easier to clear them before beginning the substitution process.

key_concept.definition: If an equation contains fractions, multiply both sides by the least common denominator (LCD) to clear them. This creates an equivalent equation with integer coefficients, making subsequent algebra easier.
key_concept.context: Working with fractions is fine, but clearing them early can reduce the chance of arithmetic errors.

worked_examples.title: Clearing Fractions Before Substitution

image.caption: Figure 7.4.8: Solve by first clearing fractions.

worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by first clearing fractions:
a) $\begin{cases} \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{1}{3}y = 4 \\ x - y = 2 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} \frac{2}{3}x - \frac{1}{2}y = 1 \\ 3x + 2y = 12 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: a) Clear fractions in first equation
b) Clear fractions in first equation
Isolate y? Or x? Let's isolate x from second?

worked_examples.concept_applied: Clear fractions early to work with integer coefficients.

image.alt: Summary of clearing fractions before substitution
image.caption: Figure 7.4.9: Clearing fractions summary.

sections.introduction: Decimals can be handled similarly to fractions—clear them by multiplying by an appropriate power of 10.

key_concept.definition: To clear decimals, multiply each equation by the power of 10 that makes all coefficients integers. For example, multiply by 10 if there are tenths, by 100 if there are hundredths, etc.
key_concept.context: Working with decimals is possible, but clearing them to integers reduces the chance of decimal arithmetic errors.

worked_examples.title: Clearing Decimals Before Substitution

image.caption: Figure 7.4.12: Solve by first clearing decimals.

worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by first clearing decimals:
a) $\begin{cases} 0.3x + 0.2y = 1.5 \\ 2x - y = 4 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 1.2x - 0.5y = 3.6 \\ 0.4x + 0.3y = 1.4 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: a) Clear decimals in first equation
b) Clear decimals in both equations

worked_examples.concept_applied: Clear decimals by multiplying by appropriate powers of 10.

image.alt: Summary of clearing decimals before substitution
image.caption: Figure 7.4.13: Clearing decimals summary.

sections.introduction: Sometimes equations contain parentheses that need to be distributed before substitution.

key_concept.definition: When equations contain parentheses, distribute first to simplify. This may create like terms that can be combined, making the equation easier to work with before isolating a variable.
key_concept.context: Failing to distribute correctly is a common source of errors. Take time to simplify each equation fully before proceeding.

worked_examples.title: Systems with Parentheses
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by first distributing and simplifying:
a) $\begin{cases} 2(x + 3) - y = 11 \\ 3x + 2y = 8 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 3(x - 2) + 2y = 5 \\ 4x - 3(y + 1) = 7 \end{cases}$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Distribute first to simplify equations before isolating variables.

image.alt: Summary of handling parentheses in substitution
image.caption: Figure 7.4.17: Parentheses handling summary.

sections.introduction: In some systems, neither variable is easy to isolate. We still choose one, even if it introduces fractions.

introduction_image.alt: Systems where both variables have coefficients
introduction_image.caption: Figure 7.4.18: No easy isolation.

key_concept.definition: When no variable has coefficient 1 or -1, we must isolate a variable anyway, accepting that fractions will appear. Choose the variable with the smallest coefficients to minimize fraction complexity.
key_concept.context: This is where substitution becomes more algebraically intensive, but still manageable with careful work.

worked_examples.title: Isolating with Fractions
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by substitution (fractions will appear):
a) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 12 \\ 5x - 2y = 11 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 3x + 4y = 10 \\ 2x - 5y = 3 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: a) Isolate x from first equation
b) Isolate y from first equation? Or x?

worked_examples.concept_applied: Even when fractions appear, substitution still works. Just be careful with the algebra.

sections.introduction: The substitution method extends to systems with three variables, though it becomes more complex.

key_concept.definition: For a system of three equations with three variables, we can use substitution to reduce it to two equations, then to one. This is an extension of the same principle: isolate one variable and substitute into the other equations.
key_concept.context: This is a preview of more advanced topics. The principle remains the same: isolate and substitute.

worked_examples.title: Three-Variable System (Preview)
worked_examples.problem: Solve the system (optional challenge): $\begin{cases} x + y + z = 6 \\ 2x - y + z = 3 \\ x + 2y - z = 2 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: Now we have two equations in y and z

worked_examples.concept_applied: Substitution extends to three variables: isolate one, substitute into the others, reduce to two equations, then solve.

sections.section_title: 7.4.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Advanced substitution introduces new potential errors. Awareness helps prevent them.

classifications.value: Mistakes when adding, subtracting, or multiplying fractions.
classifications.behavior: Wrong solutions, especially in complex problems.

classifications.value: Incorrectly distributing negative signs when simplifying.

image.alt: Correct vs incorrect distribution of negatives
image.caption: Figure 7.4.27: Error - distribution with negatives.

classifications.value: Not multiplying all terms by the same power of 10.

worked_examples.title: Correcting Advanced Substitution Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student solved $\begin{cases} \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{1}{3}y = 4 \\ 2x - y = 5 \end{cases}$ and got $(3, 1)$. Identify and correct any errors.

step_by_step.explanation: Student likely didn't clear fractions or made arithmetic mistake
step_by_step.calculation: Correct solution: Clear fractions first: $3x + 2y = 24$, then $2x - y = 5$

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct solution is $(\frac{34}{7}, \frac{33}{7})$. Student's arithmetic error led to $(3,1)$.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Always check solutions in both original equations, especially when fractions are involved.

image.alt: Summary table of common advanced substitution errors and corrections
image.caption: Figure 7.4.30: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to solve a variety of complex systems using advanced substitution techniques.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system using substitution. Clear fractions or decimals first where helpful.
1) $\begin{cases} \frac{2}{3}x - \frac{1}{2}y = 2 \\ 3x + 2y = 12 \end{cases}$
2) $\begin{cases} 0.4x + 0.3y = 2.6 \\ 2x - y = 5 \end{cases}$
3) $\begin{cases} 2(x - 3) + y = 4 \\ 3x - 2(y + 1) = 5 \end{cases}$
4) $\begin{cases} 4x + 3y = 10 \\ 5x - 2y = 7 \end{cases}$ (no easy isolation)
5) $\begin{cases} \frac{1}{4}x + \frac{1}{2}y = 3 \\ x - 2y = 4 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: Isolate y from first? Or x?
Add equations? Actually substitution: from second, $x = 2y + 4$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice solving complex systems using advanced substitution techniques.

summary: Advanced substitution extends the basic method to more complex systems, requiring additional algebraic skills and strategic thinking. When choosing which variable to isolate, look for coefficients of 1 or -1 to avoid fractions. When equations contain fractions, clear them by multiplying by the LCD before proceeding. For decimals, multiply by the appropriate power of 10 to get integer coefficients. Always distribute parentheses fully before isolating variables. When no variable has a simple coefficient, isolate anyway—fractions will appear, but careful algebra will yield the solution. The same principles apply to systems with three variables: isolate one variable, substitute into the other equations to reduce to two equations, then solve. Throughout, maintain careful algebra, use parentheses when substituting, and always check solutions in the original equations. Advanced substitution builds algebraic fluency and prepares students for more complex mathematical modeling.
